sections.title: Intro & heads-up
sections.content:
This document is informational only. It explains how I usually work, what I will do, and what clients should not expect. It is NOT a legal contract, it is not legally binding, it is not signed, and nothing in this document is intended to be used in court or any legal process.

By choosing to work with me, you acknowledge that this document is a practical guideline, not a legal agreement.

Who I am: Mahdi Yasser — developer and founder of VetroM. I build websites, apps, and digital products for clients worldwide.

Scope: These guidelines apply to every project I deliver unless we clearly agree on different rules before I start.

sections.title: 1. Work ownership & usage
sections.content:
I offer flexible ownership options depending on what we agree during the project scoping. I will always state which option applies before starting work.

Option A — I retain full ownership (default)

  • I permanently retain ownership of all code, frameworks, systems, and structures I build or use.
  • Payment does not transfer ownership of frameworks, architecture, or reusable systems.
  • You are granted a license to use the delivered website/app/service for your intended purpose.
  • You may not resell, redistribute, or claim the work or its internal systems as your own.

Option B — Shared / limited ownership

  • You may be granted rights to use and edit the project for your needs.
  • I retain the right to reuse, adapt, and resell code, components, or patterns that I built for your project. You may not resell the full product.

Option C — Full ownership for a head‑start period

  • You receive full ownership rights to the agreed deliverables for the duration of the head‑start period.
  • The head start is effective immediately from delivery.
  • During the head‑start period, I will not reuse, resell, replicate, or deliver the same or substantially similar work to anyone else.
  • The purpose of the head start is exclusivity: you are the only one using that solution during the agreed period.
  • After the head‑start period ends, ownership and reuse rights revert to what we agreed beforehand (for example: I may reuse general ideas, systems, or non‑exclusive components).
  • The length and exact scope of the head‑start period must be clearly agreed on before work starts.

Option D — Special agreement

  • Any ownership variations not covered above will be defined in the project agreement we write and sign before work starts.
I will always clarify and confirm which option we choose. If you want exclusive transfer of all rights, mention it before we start so I can price and draft it correctly.

sections.title: 2. System & backend (full system)
sections.content:
• "System & backend" means everything that makes the product work behind the scenes.
  • This includes, without limitation: logic, code structure, frameworks, APIs, databases, workflows, CMS functionality, admin panels, automation, configurations, integrations, and overall architecture.
  • Hosting servers are not mine. All servers belong to the hosting provider chosen by the client or agreed on together. I do not own or control hosting infrastructure unless explicitly stated.
  • I retain all rights over the system and backend I design or use, unless we explicitly agree otherwise.
  • You are granted the rights needed to use and manage your product, but not to resell, redistribute, or claim ownership of the system or backend.
  • Any transfer of ownership or exclusivity over the system and backend must be explicitly agreed on before work starts and may affect pricing.

sections.title: 3. Design, style and content reuse
sections.content:
• I may reuse design patterns, components, or stylistic elements I created for you in other projects. Visual similarity of generic elements does not mean your project has been copied — it’s normal for designers to reuse proven patterns.
  • If we agree that certain assets or styles are exclusive to your project, that exclusivity will be written into the project agreement.

sections.title: 4. After-delivery support (bug fixes & edits)
sections.content:
I provide a post-delivery support window. The exact length is defined in the project agreement, but standard practice is up to 21 days after delivery.

During the support window (0–21 days by default):

  • I will fix bugs I introduced and handle small edits included in the agreed scope.
  • Any major new features or scope changes will be treated as a new paid project.

After the support window ends:

  • Ongoing work, bug-fixing, or changes are not automatically included and will require a new agreement.
  • I am not obligated to accept or perform additional work after this period, though I may offer paid options if you ask.

sections.title: 5. Payment & pricing
sections.content:
• If the service or package is listed on VetroM’s public services page at a price, that is the price you pay unless we agree otherwise in writing.
  • Standard deposit is 50% (half) before I start for fixed-price projects listed as services; the deposit rate can be changed only by me and will be stated in the project agreement.
  • For custom projects not listed on the services page, price and payment schedule are set by mutual agreement and may change with scope.
  • If we agree on a fixed price explicitly in writing, that fixed price applies and I won’t change it for scope that matches what we documented.
  • Payment method and schedule will be defined in the project agreement and must be respected by the client.

Free trials (if offered):

  • Trials are intended to show the concept or confirm the product is working and well-received. They are not open-ended evaluation periods.
  • Trial period will not exceed 21 days unless I explicitly agree to more.
  • I may end a trial early if the product proves successful and require payment at that point.

sections.title: 6. Revisions & change requests
sections.content:
• I include the number of revisions agreed in the project scope. Extra revisions or scope changes may incur additional fees.
  • Major changes that alter the original scope will be treated as additional work and priced accordingly.

sections.title: 7. Client responsibilities
sections.content:
• Provide accurate content, access, and materials I request in a timely manner.
  • Ensure your supplied content (text, images, logos, prices, data, code, etc.) does not infringe copyrights, laws, or third‑party rights.

Response time for requested data:

  • When I request required data for the project (for example: images, text, prices, product details, credentials), the client must provide it as soon as possible (ASAP).
  • Unless we explicitly agree otherwise, ASAP means within 24 hours of the request.
  • If the client delays beyond the agreed time, a delay fine may apply, calculated per hour.
  • Unless stated otherwise, the default fine is 250 EGP per hour of delay.

Logic‑based exceptions:

  • Some requests naturally require more time (for example: collecting restaurant food images, menus, or real‑world assets).
  • In such cases, I and the client may agree on a longer, reasonable deadline based on logic and real constraints.
  • When a special deadline is agreed on, that agreed time replaces the default 24‑hour rule.

sections.title: 8. Use, abuse, and prohibited requests
sections.content:
• I will not build or support anything illegal, unethical, or that violates platform terms (spam tools, malware, scams, copyright-breaking systems, etc.).
  • If the client uses delivered work in a way that causes legal problems, misuse, or damage, I am not liable for the consequences.

sections.title: 9. Liability & warranty
sections.content:
• I will deliver work that meets the agreed scope and quality standards.
  • I am not liable for indirect losses, lost profits, or damage arising from use of the delivered product.
  • Any guarantees for uptime, security, or performance must be written into the agreement — otherwise, no implied warranty.

sections.title: 10. Termination and cancellations
sections.content:
• Either party can cancel a project. Work already performed is billable.
  • Paid work is non-refundable unless we agree otherwise.

sections.title: 11. Portfolio, publicity & testimonials
sections.content:
• I may publicly state that I worked with you and include the project in my portfolio, case studies, or marketing materials.
  • I may use screenshots, code excerpts, or public-facing materials from the project unless we agreed on privacy or nondisclosure in writing.
  • I may publish a testimonial from you, but only after you agree to provide one. Clients are expected to give one testimonial when requested and agreed during project closure.

sections.title: 12. Final notes & how we agree changes
sections.content:
• This document does not create a legal relationship or enforceable obligations.
  • Nothing here can be used as legal evidence or relied on in court.
  • The version discussed at the start of the project is the version that applies for practical expectations only.
  • If there is disagreement about what was agreed, this document serves only as a reference of general working style, not proof.
  • Any changes or exceptions are handled informally by mutual understanding before work begins.

sections.title: Privacy Policy — how I handle client info
sections.content:
What I collect:

  • Contact details (name, email, phone) and any files or data you provide for the project.

Why I collect it:

  • To communicate, design, develop, invoice, and deliver the project.

How I use it:

  • Project communication and delivery.
  • Troubleshooting and support during the agreed support window.

Sharing & third parties:

  • I am a solo freelancer and I do not sell your personal info.
  • I may share minimal project details with partners or service providers only when necessary for the project and only with your consent.

Security & retention:

  • I take reasonable measures to protect your data while I hold it.
  • I keep data only as long as necessary to support the project or meet legal obligations.

Portfolio & publicity (again):

  • I reserve the right to mention and show the project in my portfolio and marketing, unless we agreed to specific restrictions.

Your rights:

  • Ask me what data I hold about the project or request deletion of non-essential personal data.
